Hi, I'm Alex McAdams and I'm a physics
programmer working on Chaos Cloth for
Unreal Engine. Uh before coming to Epic,
I was an engineer at Disney Animation,
also working on hair and cloth
simulation. I worked with Jared Monson
on series cloth for the Witcher 4 Unreal
5 tech demo, and we're excited to use
this experience to share some of the
best practices for using Chaos Cloth in
AAA game
workflows. It's just a quick video to
remind you of what the cloth looked
like.
So, in this talk, we're going to go
through the process of setting up cloth
assets for a game from design to rigging
and in-game controls with the inevitable
compromises that you end up making when
under project deadlines.
So before you start building your cloth
asset, you'll need to consider both
artistic and performance goals for your
cloth. Oftent times this process starts
with concept art like this, sometimes
with a few variations. Now can be a good
time to raise potential simulation
issues and brainstorm solutions. For
example, this version of series cloak
has a lot of small folds that can pose
simulation challenges both in terms of
resolution required to simulate the
folds as well as the number of potential
self-colision
issues. Thankfully, a heavier simpler
sim to simulate version was ultimately
chosen.
Now, when determining the level of
detail we want to include in our
simulation proxy mesh, we need to
consider both performance targets and
art direction. In particular, for Siri,
we had a budget of under 1 millisecond
on PS5, and we knew that her cloak was
made from long, heavy material.
Furthermore, we had to prepare for
complex collisions between Siri's body,
swords, and the horse.
While Chaos Cloth has a wide range of
features to support anything from
real-time game simulations up to
cinematic quality cloth, we'll be
focusing on which settings are
appropriate for game quality cloth in
this talk. In particular, when targeting
a typical game, we recommend simulation
meshes with a resolution of around 200
to 600 simulated vertices. significantly
more vertices can push into the
cinematic cloth quality which can
require more complex
setups. Uh for aesthetics with a typical
level of features for cloaks and capes
and things like that, we tend to
recommend around 350 simulated vertices.
This allows for enough degrees of
freedom while staying in a half to one
millisecond range on current generation
hardware.
I also wanted to highlight that for 5.6
we've done some optimization targeting
platforms such as mobile and have found
that around 200 simulated vertices works
well coming in at around 1 millisecond
per frame on these
platforms. So once we've got the
specifications for our cloth asset, it's
time to rig
it. One of the first inputs you'll need
to generate for your cloth asset is your
simulation proxy mesh. We've talked a
bit about the recommended resolution,
but we also need to consider things like
edge
flow. The main thing to remember when
creating your simulation mesh is that
cloth can only bend along mesh edges. At
cinematic quality, this can have an
effect on wrinkle bias, but mostly you
have enough degrees of freedom to bend
any way you want. On the other hand, on
this game quality, edge flow will have a
real effect on the bulk behavior of your
simulation. Uh the right image here uh
it shows the simulation proxy we used
for series cloak and we found that
similar quadbased meshes with attention
to diagonal triangulation tends to work
well when making similar cloaks and
capes. We have a few different ways to
import your meshes into the cloth asset,
but one that gives the most control is
by importing from a skeletal mesh. The
cloth asset will import both the mesh
geometry as well as any normals, UVs,
skin weights, and render colors and
materials. And new in 5.6, we also
support importing simulation morph
targets. Another type of asset you
author outside of the cloth editor and
import in is the physics asset. This
asset contains kinematic collision
bodies for the simulation that are
driven by a skeletal mesh. While the
physics asset supports a way uh a range
of types of collisions including
convexes and skin meshes, uh we
recommend using simple rounded
primitives like this. So tapered
capsules, capsules, and spheres wherever
possible. They're both performant and
they lack corners that can cause
snags. Once you have these assets, we'll
use the chaos cloth editor to do the
rest of our cloth asset rigging.
The core of the chaos cloth editor is a
data flow graph. This node graph is a
construction graph made up of nodes
corresponding to operations like adding
constraints, remeshing, painting weight
maps, or editing solver settings. The
terminal node of the graph compiles this
data into the final cloth
asset. The editor has two viewports
which you can see here. The construction
viewport by default is on the left. and
it corresponds with the state of the
asset up to the corres uh the currently
selected node. From here we can view the
assets three sets of geometry. The
render geometry, the 3D simulation proxy
and a 2D panel-based version of the
simulation proxy.
The right-hand viewport is what we call
the simulation viewport and can be used
to preview your cloth asset with
optional animations and also that's
where our simulation debug display is.
If you're familiar with the skeletal
meshbased cloth editor, this corresponds
with the viewport
there. If you're interested in learning
more about how to use dataf flow, I'd
recommend you check out the
non-destructive workflows for chaos
physics in UA5 session later this
afternoon.
Now, Chaos Cloth offers several types of
constraints, but some of the biggest
decision points are which constraint
types to use for stretching, bending,
and self collisions. So, I'm going to
walk through these options and our
recommendations for game
assets. on both our stretch and bin
simulation nodes. One of the properties
you'll find is solver type with the
option of PBD or
XPBD. For assets with the resolution
we're using here, we recommend using
PBD. It's computationally fast and has a
simple to author 0 to1 stiffness values.
Uh the main feature that XPBD offers is
constraint damping, but we found this
feature is more useful for the high
resolution cinematic quality cloth with
high subframe
counts. Now, let's take a look a little
bit more at our stretch
constraints. Uh the first checked box
you'll see is whether or not to use 3D
rest links. You want to keep this
checked on unless you have a simulation

cloth editing package uh that can be

top is an example where we do have that

But in our case uh we have just a

the 3D render mesh. So we'll be using
the 3D rest
links. Uh once you've done those first

option to add an area constraint which
can add extra stability to the
simulation. We I recommend adding it
depending on which bending model you
choose. So I'll talk about this a little
bit more in a
bit. The last uh stretch constraint
option I wanted to highlight was enable
stretch warp and we scale. Uh, this
allows you to change the rest length of
the

runtime. So, that was stretch
constraints. Now, let's take a look at
bending constraints. The big choice you
have is between what we call hinge or
faces spring.
The hinge constraint is a angle
constraint on each edge of the mesh. The
faces spring is a spring that con is
that connects opposite vertices from an
edge. So the hinge is like the
constraint on the blue and the face
spring is the red
spring. Hinge constraints are good at
holding a specific angle and work well
for cloth that has a lot of structure.
We use them on series hood for this
reason. Uh, one drawback of the hinge
constraint is it can be less stable
under a lot of stretching. And this is
part of why we like to use it with the
area constraint I mentioned
before. The face spring constraint is
good for softer, more dynamic objects
like the cloak. Uh, this constraint is
very cheap and stable, but it can't hold
specific angles as well.
Uh so the final simulation property

self collision
options. The most expensive option is

very expensive and it would have
completely blown up our submillisecond
budget.

each

makes these useful for supporting self
collisions is that you have a separate
compression versus extension stiffness.
So in the case of series cloak, we set
the springs to only engage when they
shorten beyond an initial configuration.
This keeps the cloak from collapsing in
on itself while remaining free to expand
out.
The last configuration node I wanted to
talk about is our solver
settings. Solver settings control how
each sub each frame is subdivided. The
first level of the subdivision is the
number of substeps per frame. In this
case, we have two substeps per frame
denoted in orange and where the total
cost of the frame is equal to the
substep cost plus a fixed frame setup
and finalized cost.
Each substep is further divided by a
number of iterations. Here we have two
red iterations per substep. Similar to
the frame level, there's also an
additional cost per substep where we
advance time for kinematic objects as
well as setup self
collisions. We recommend starting out
with a minimum of one substep.
the view uh one one iteration and one

increasing substeps and iterations to

increasing substeps can help substeps

of

number of substeps. So, it may take some

balance.
